metadata.title: Paradoxical V ocal Fold Movement  Children and Adolescents
synonyms: paradoxical vocal fold motion dysfunction, pvfmd
vocal fold movement, paradoxical: children and adolescents
paradoxical vocal fold motion dysfunction: children and adolescents
area of specialty: v oice and v oice disorders
description: Paradoxical vocal fold movement (PVFM) refers to a condition in which the vocal folds close rather than open in unpredictable episodes during inhalation and/or exhalation.(1) Symptoms vary but include wheezing, hoarseness, stridor (i.e., high-pitched sound produced by turbulent airflow in restricted airway), and difficulty breathing (dyspnea).(2) PVFM often co-occurs  with asthma and is often confused with asthma in children and adolescents(3)

ICD-10 codes.J38.3: other diseases of vocal cords (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The patient will present with some or all of the following signs and symptoms:
Stridor that occurs primarily with inhalation and sometimes upon exhalation(3,4)
Tightness in the throat or upper chest(5)
Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)(5) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Refer for otorhinolaryngological and laryngo-videostroboscopic examinations if these have not been performed

pathogenesis: PVFM: The pathogenesis of PVFM depends on the cause. See Causes , above
risk factors: PVFM in children and adolescents has been linked to participation in competitive sports and orientation towards highachievement(3,5)

overall contraindications precautions: Precautions will vary according to the individual patient The patient’s medical records should be reviewed thoroughly prior to evaluation or treatment. Neurologic and respiratory conditions can affect the voice(6) The course of PVFM is usually in a nonprogressive pattern, with fluctuation in symptom severity or attacks; in contrast, a progressive airway obstruction might signify a potentially more dangerous airway obstruction, such as a tumor. Patients must receive a thorough medical (laryngeal) examination by an otolaryngologist prior to a voice assessment.(7) A speech-language  pathologist (SLP) in a school setting or a clinic might become the primary advocate for a laryngeal

contraindications precautions to examina: Refer for otorhinolaryngological and laryngo-videostroboscopic examinations if these have not been performed

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the onset of symptoms. Are the symptoms progressive or sporadic? Do symptoms occur primarily after exercise, or during stressful situations (e.g., school exams)?(5) Children and adolescents often experience PVFM after periods of intense physical activity.(1) If the patient feels an obstruction, where does the obstruction occur? Did the condition begin after an upper respiratory infection or illness?(1) Are there triggers, such as exercise, exertion, hyperventilation, laughing, or airborne irritants (e.g., dust)?(1)

course of treatment.medical management: Document any medical examinations by physicians, such as an otolaryngologist. Document any medical management for other conditions such as respiratory conditions or LPR. Has the patient had surgery of the head or neck? Has the patient had a tracheostomy? Severe acute episodes of PVFM might be treated with heliox, which is a combination of helium (80%) and oxygen (20%) that decreases airflow turbulence and resistance by promoting laminar flow (smooth regular patterns of airflow) through the airway(26)  Severe acute episodes of PVFM are sometimes treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) as well(26)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Determine if any medications negatively affect vocal hygiene (e.g., side effect of xerostomia [dry mouth])
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Tests for this condition might include the following:
Psychological evaluation if there is evidence of a psychological component(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had previous speech-language  therapy for this or for other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there times of day in which the patient’s voice is better/worse? Does participation in certain activities make the child’s symptoms better or worse? Dysphonia that is worse in the morning than at night is indicative of GERD(8)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Symptoms of PVFM during an attack sometimes occur only during inspiration, but they can occur -dyspnea(26) -sensation of choking(4) -stridor(4,26) -wheezing(26) -chronic hoarseness(4) -tightness in larynx, throat, or chest(3,26) -Symptoms usually subside when the triggering event (e.g., exercise)ceases
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if laryngeal pain or discomfort is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night), if any; also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Symptoms of asthma occur at night and cause nocturnal awaking, whereas symptoms of PVFM rarely occur at night
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (difficulties breathing/GERD, cold/flu/allergies/ asthma). GERD is associated with chronic hoarseness and vocal nodules in children and adolescents.(6) Use child-friendly language to describe medical conditions such as GERD, as necessary (e.g., "sour burps," "little throw-ups")(8)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note any respiratory disorder (e.g., asthma) or symptoms that might influence vocal quality. Does the patient have wheezing or impaired breathing? Is the patient regularly exposed to tobacco smoke? Does the patient drink beverages that contain caffeine?Does the patient have general anxiety or anxiety about his or her speech? Is the patient reluctant to talk? Psychosocial stressors such as parental divorce, parent-child  conflict, and parental anxiety about patient performance have been found to be associated with PVFM.(1) A cycle of anxiety has been described in which PVFM triggers difficulty breathing and anxiety in the patient, which in turn provokes anxiety in the parent. An emotional reaction might then exacerbate the disorder. Refer to a psychologist or counselor as necessary(1)Document hearing abilities, including hearing loss and use of hearing aids or cochlear implants Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has another voice disorder, a communication disorder, or anxiety previously been diagnosed in the patient?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient and/or family/caregivers about concomitant medical diagnoses that might affect voice or respiratory system (e.g., allergies, asthma, hearing impairment)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient and/or family/caregivers about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: It is important to take a complete medical history that includes patterns of vocational and social vocal behavior to determine factors that contribute to the disorder. PVFM can lead to difficulties in completing academic work and participating in class, difficulties socializing, and depression(9) -Has PVFM disrupted the patient’s class participation or participation in social activities? -Does the patient participate in recreational hobbies or competitive sports?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: How does PVFM affect functional communication? Does the patient use any adaptive equipment for communicating (e.g., pen and paper when the voice is severely impaired)?Identify the patient's living situation and potential communication difficulties that the patient might be experiencing at home. Does the house have excessive background noise (e.g., television, music)? Do other family members talk loudly or have voice difficulties? Does any member of the family have a hearing impairment? Does anyone in the house smoke?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting) •Oral mechanism exam and related tests:  Conduct an assessment of the patient’s oral motor structures and functions
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Document any vision or hearing loss. Perform a hearing screening if loss is suspected
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisA laryngeal examination must be completed by an experienced pediatric otolaryngologist in order to rule out laryngeal growths, such as nodules, polyps, recurrent laryngeal papillomata, tumors, contact ulcers, and laryngeal webs. In addition, the laryngeal examination serves to determine the position of the larynx (e.g., high, low) and any other characteristics of the vocal folds, including vocal fold closure and physical aspects of the folds (e.g., swollen, tense). The patient should be referred for a follow-up  biopsy if a growth is identified. Laryngeal examinations involve anyA mirror examination involves placing a mirror in the back of the patient’s throat. V ocal folds can be visualized by reflecting light down to the voice box(11)Rigid endoscopy is performed with a rigid tube placed into the oral or pharyngeal cavity. A rigid laryngoscope provides the clearest view of the larynx; however, the tongue needs to be held by the examiner, and normal speech production cannot be performed during the examination. A flexible laryngoscope uses fiberoptic technology and can be passed through the nose to the back of the throat, allowing for examination of the larynx during voicing. Flexible laryngoscopes might be better tolerated by children and adolescents who have sensitive gag reflexes.(12) When the patient is symptomatic, PVFM typically appears as adduction (closing) of the anterior two thirds of the vocal cords with a slight posterior opening in the form of a diamond shape.(5) Medialization of the ventricular folds might also occur.(1) When the patient is asymptomatic, laryngeal structure and function appear to be normal with laryngoscopy(1)Videostroboscopic examination allows the examiner to see the vocal folds vibrating in slow motion and gives information on any abnormalities present during voice production (e.g., abnormal closure). It is performed with instrumentation used for oral endoscopy or nasendoscopy and is combined with a strobe light correlated to vocal fold vibration(12)Electroglottography is a system to provide information on vocal fold closure by measuring the electrical resistance of two electrodes placed around the neck(12) A handheld tool that can be used to measure respiratory resistance over time; provides an objective measure of changes in inspiratory and expiratory respiratory resistance that result from PVFM(30)The SLP should get information regarding the onset of PVFM, possible triggers of PVFM, nature of the breathing difficulty, any previous respiratory disease or difficulties, patient’s regular vocal activities (e.g., singing, yelling during sports), and recent voice changes. The SLP can informally evaluate the patient’s vocal quality, muscle tension, and breathing patterns during an interview. A family member or parent/caregiver can be included in the interview as needed(13)Identify the voice’s perceptual and acoustic characteristics with perceptual and instrumental measures if the patient exhibits any dysphonia. Observe the patient’s behavior (e.g., evidence of neck strain) during voicing or voicing attempts(10) -Acoustic measures of voice might include signal-to-noise  ratio, jitter (pitch perturbation), and shimmer (amplitude perturbation). Computerized voice analysis programs such as the Multi-Dimension V oice Program (MDVP) allow the clinician to calculate these voice parameters and compare the patient’s results to normative data provided in the programThe patient is asked to take a deep breath and sustain the vowel /a/ for as long as(14)3-11 seconds5-15 seconds5-16 seconds5-20 secondsNumber of syllables or words produced on one expiratory flowThe length of time a patient can produce “S” over the length of time the patient can produce “Z.” A number greater than 1.4 indicates difficulty with movement of the vocal folds. Normal value is 1Low to high and high to low. Listen for pitch breaks, reduced range, tension, and cessation of voicingDuring tasks such as counting and reading passages, the examiner can assess -Are the inhalations stridulous (high-pitched and noisy)? -Is air released prior to phonation? -Does the patient have shortness of breath? -Does the patient’s vocal quality change as the breath diminishes at the end of exhalation? -Is the voice weak or breathy? -Is the patient’s voicing effortful or forced?Observe patient for any muscle tension in the neck, jaw, shoulders, face, or lipsObserve patient's breath support during sustained phonation, at rest, and during conversationThe Consensus Auditory-Perceptual  Evaluation of V oice (CAPE-V)  is available on the//www.asha.org/uploadedFiles/members/divs/ D3CAPEVprocedures.pdf ) and can be used to systematically describe the severity of auditory-perceptual  characteristics of the voice. The results can be considered with those of other instrumental measures to contribute to hypotheses regarding the anatomic and physiological bases of voice problems. The patient is asked to produce sustained vowels, overall severity, roughness, breathiness, strain, pitch, and loudness(15)Research has indicated that voice disorders in children and adolescents can lead to negative attention from peers and/or teachers and reduced participation in school and social activities.(17)Quality of life measures have been found to reflect significant impairment in social-emotional and physical-functional  domains for children and adolescents with voice disorders(18)A 10-item  pediatric voice outcomes instrument(19)A 23-item outcome measure based on the adult VHI(20)A quality of life instrument validated for adults with breathing disorders; authors of a study conducted in the United States with 56 children and adolescents (ages 12 to 18) who had the diagnosis of exercise-induced  PVFM reported that the DI was valid and reliable for assessing quality of life in this population as well(16)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Identify any articulation, fluency, or receptive or expressive language concerns and assess with informal and formal measures as necessary.(10) For detailed information on speech and language disorders in children, see the series of Clinical Reviews on these topics

other: Children with PVFM often have difficulty breathing, and in extreme cases difficulty breathing caused by PVFM can lead to loss of consciousness.(3) If the child exhibits severe symptoms of respiratory distress, refer immediately to emergency medical services

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: An otolaryngologist will make the diagnosis of PVFM. Intervention for PVFM is required and often involves numerous disciplines(1)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Tracheal diseases such as tracheomalacia, intrinsic or extrinsic neoplastic laryngotracheal growths, and bronchial/ pulmonary disease (asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD]) must be ruled out by a physician. Asthma is the most common lower airway disease, whereas PVFM is an upper airway disease.(4) Most patients with PVFM present with stridor, one of the main differentiating factors between upper and lower airway obstruction.(4) However, asthma often co-occurs  with PVFM, further complicating diagnosis.(26) When a patient is having an asthma attack, the oxygen saturation levels of the blood will decrease; however, during an acute PVFM attack, oxygen saturation levels remain normal(26)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to a counselor or psychologist when underlying emotional or psychological issues that trigger PVFM need to be addressed by a professional(3)
treatment summary: Medical intervention for PVFM involves patient and family education, termination of unnecessary medications that appear to exacerbate the condition, and prescription of medications to treat underlying causes of PVFM (e.g., medications to treat GERD)(1)

The primary objective of speech therapy for PVFM is to teach the patient how to control the laryngeal area and to maintain a relaxed and open airway during respiration. In addition, the SLP might be involved in diagnostic input, patient and parent education, supportive counseling, and voice therapy(1) –Therapy for PVFM is called laryngeal control therapy; laryngeal control therapy involves teaching the patient to use diaphragmatic breathing to decrease throat tension and promote passive inspiration.(26) Additionally, the patient is taught to relax the upper body, especially the neck, during speech and at rest and is educated about the use of vocal hygiene measures (e.g., adequate water intake, eliminating of throat clearing and shouting)(26) -Laryngeal control breathing techniques (LCBTs) focus on having the patient use noisy nasal inhalation with lips tightly closed followed by noisy exhalation through pursed lips. These techniques are combined with diaphragmatic breathing to increase efficiency and control(28) -Initial therapy sessions should focus on performing and perfecting LCBTs in isolation and then move on to functional situations that are known to trigger episodes(28) –In a retrospective chart review study conducted in the United States that included104 patients (adolescents and adults) with symptoms of PVFM that were exercise-related  only, researchers found that laryngeal control therapy was effective in managing these symptoms.(26) Sixty-seven  of the patients identified to have exercise-induced  PVFM enrolled in laryngeal control therapy, and of these 48 (72%) exhibited improvement in or complete resolution of symptoms related to exercise-induced PVFM(26)

Authors of an evidence-based  systematic review of the literature on speech therapy treatment for PVFM reported finding 65 studies or reports; two of these were randomized controlled trials and 50 were case reports. In total, there were 420 individuals included in the studies, ranging in age from 8 years to 87 years; 32 of the studies reviewed included children.(21) Authors of this review concluded that, although the evidence for speech therapy for the treatment of PVFM  was promising, additional, well-controlled  studies are needed. Treatment techniques cited in most of the studies included in this review were: –focusing on performing active exhalations(21) –relaxing the muscles of the mouth and throat(21) –providing patient education about how to voluntarily control the vocal folds(21) –teaching breathing techniques such as diaphragmatic breathing, open throat breathing, and coordinated thoracic-abdominal  breathing(21) –counseling(21) –providing information about vocal hygiene(21) –exercising inspiratory muscles(21)

Authors of a review of literature summarized the treatment protocol for children with PVFM: –Education: teach the child about the anatomy and physiology of the larynx and diaphragm; ensure the child understands the purpose of therapy (to learn ways to prevent, reduce, or eliminate PFVM)(27) –Awareness: increase the child’s awareness of what episodes of PVFM look, sound, and feel like(27) –Therapy techniques -Inhalation techniques: diaphragmatic breathing; diaphragmatic sniff (“smell the flowers”) to reduce upper torso tension and increase vocal fold abductor activity(27) -Exhalation techniques: blowing out a candle or hissing; exhaling through pursed lips to reduce laryngeal constriction(27) -Relaxation exercises (including laryngeal massage)(27) -Rhythmic breathing: breathing to a beat and learning to maintain that during physical activities/exercise(27) -Cognitive training: positive self-talk,  visual imagery(27) -V ocal hygiene(27) -Generalization: transferring techniques learned in therapy to functional situations that typically trigger episodes of PVFM(27)

The child and family might need to be convinced of the effectiveness of a behavioral approach to treatment, particularly if the child previously had a misdiagnosis of asthma and has had ineffective treatment(3)

A school-based  SLP will refer the child or adolescent to an SLP in a medical setting for evaluation and treatment but might play a role in monitoring the patient during school and educating school staff about the nature of PVFM and its treatment(3)

Treatments for pediatric voice disorders are similar to those used in adults with voice disorders, with the following suggested modifications: –Use of child-friendly  language (e.g., “smell the flowers” when teaching about diaphragmatic breathing)(8,29) –Involvement of parent/caregiver and teacher in therapy sessions to facilitate home practice and carry-over(8) –Additional sessions to achieve treatment goals(8) –The use of age-appropriate  activities in voice therapy(23) –The use of visuals (watching themselves in the mirror) or video to explain concepts relating to PVFM, such as laryngeal and respiratory function(29)

Research on interventions for PVFM in children and adolescents is limited. The following are case studies and clinical reports that have described the effects of treatment: –Biofeedback training:  A 16-year-old  girl with PVFM received surface electromyography (EMG) biofeedback training once a week over the course of 10 weeks. During biofeedback sessions, EMG surface electrodes were placed along a parallel axis of the thyrohyoid membrane, using the thyroid cartilage as an anatomical marker.(24) The girl was asked to try to relax and lower her observed muscle tension below a preset criterion. No instructions were given on how to accomplish the relaxation other than "try to relax the muscle tension near your vocal cords to below the criterion line on the computer screen, using the feedback to guide you." A new criterion level was set after the current criterion was met in three consecutive sessions. Baseline muscle tension levels decreased over 60%, with reductions in episodes of respiratory distress and chest pain. The girl and girl's family reported overall improvement in school attendance and adaptive functioning(24)  –Instruction in deep breathing: The authors of a clinical report described a 15-year-old  female competitive swimmer who had a 3-week  history of shortness of breath and a wheezy, irregular breathing pattern while swimming. The patient also described a "blockage" in the throat.(3) During a flexible fiberoptic examination of the larynx, signs of irritation due to LPR were observed. These included swollen, red arytenoids and swelling of the lower edges of the vocal folds. The patient was asked to reproduce the blockage and wheezy feeling during inhalation. With the endoscope in place, the patient was asked to perform breathing exercises to maintain vocal fold abduction. She could then visualize how a deep nasal sniff during inspiration could abduct the vocal folds. She learned to coordinate this deep breathing in the pool by slowing her pace, and she also practiced this technique at home. Additionally, she was given behavioral techniques to reduce LPR. Complete resolution of her symptoms occurred after 2 weeks . maintenance or prevention: As part of the therapy process, children and adolescents and their families should receive information on good vocal hygiene (e.g., maintaining adequate hydration, reducing exposure to smoke, eliminating irritants to vocal folds such as acid reflux and pollution, reducing abusive behaviors such as excessive shouting and throat clearing)
